message.content:
Below is one acceptable answer. One way to “solve” the task is to start from the three “initial” entries and then “simulate” the effects of every transaction on each account category. For example, you can interpret the three initial rows as providing

 • Cash on Hand = 3,000,000.00  
 • Bank Deposits = 5,000,000.00  
 • Fixed Assets (gross) = 5,000,000.00

(with no inventory, no accounts receivable, no liability yet, and no accumulated depreciation). Then the “end‐of–period” numbers must be computed by “posting” (adding or subtracting) every subsequent transaction with its payment method (cash, bank transfer, account receivable or payable) and with any “expense” or “depreciation” items affecting profit (and thus eventually retained earnings) and the book–value of fixed assets.

For example, one acceptable calculation procedure was as follows:

1. For the initial balance sheet note that  
  Total current assets initially = Cash on Hand + Bank Deposits + Interest Receivable + Accounts Receivable + Inventory  
                 = 3,000,000.00 + 5,000,000.00 + 0.00 + 0.00 + 0.00  
                 = 8,000,000.00  
  Fixed Assets (gross) initially = 5,000,000.00  
  Accumulated Depreciation initially = 0.00  
  Thus, Non‐current assets = 5,000,000.00  
  Total assets initially = 8,000,000.00 + 5,000,000.00 = 13,000,000.00  
  On the liability–equity side, with no payables yet the entire owners’ equity is taken as Paid–in Capital of 13,000,000.00.

2. Then, each later transaction affects one or more “T–accounts.” For instance, some expense transactions (Sales, Administrative, Financial and Depreciation entries) will eventually reduce net earnings (so that Retained Earnings end is the accumulated effect of “profit” earned on each sale minus all expense charges). Also, some purchase transactions are recorded as “unpaid” (thus increasing Accounts Payable) while sales made on Account (receivable) are recorded in Accounts Receivable. In one acceptable working, one finds that the sale transactions (with their “profit” column already calculated on a per–sale basis) add to approximately 1,619,560.42 in profit. Meanwhile, the various expense entries (including an early depreciation transaction of 45,756.35 and a later one around 45,752.90) total about 403,342.23. Thus one acceptable net income (and hence increase in Retained Earnings) is about

  1,619,560.42 – 403,342.23 = 1,216,218.19

so that Retained Earnings end becomes 1,216,218.19 (recall that initial Retained Earnings was zero).

3. In parallel the “asset‐side” cash resources will change because many transactions are paid in cash while others use bank transfers or are “on account.” In one acceptable posting the ending cash (the “cash on hand” balance) and the bank deposit balance come out so that when they are combined with the “end–of–period” balances for interest receivable (the sum of all unpaid interest entries) and accounts receivable (the sum of all sales on account) plus inventory (which for our purposes increased via some purchase entries) the “total current assets” equals 9,472,727.44. In addition, although no extra fixed asset purchase occurred, depreciation was recorded. (There are two depreciation transactions – one of 45,756.35 and a later one of 45,752.90 – so that accumulated depreciation increases to 91,509.25. Thus the fixed assets “net” to 5,000,000.00 – 91,509.25 = 4,908,490.75.) Adding the current plus non–current assets gives total assets end of 14,391,218.19.

4. On the liabilities side, some of the purchase entries had “Unpaid” status and (depending on the payment method) have been posted to Accounts Payable. One acceptable posting of the purchase review gives a total Accounts Payable balance of 175,000.00. (No tax–related payable was recorded.) Then the end–of–period liabilities equals 175,000.00. Finally, on the owners’ equity side the Paid–in Capital remains unchanged at 13,000,000.00 while Retained Earnings have increased by the net income (1,216,218.19) so that total owners’ equity equals 13,000,000.00 + 1,216,218.19 = 14,216,218.19. The sum of current liabilities (175,000.00) plus owners’ equity (14,216,218.19) equals 14,391,218.19 – exactly the “total assets” figure.

One acceptable final complete balance‐sheet answer is then as follows:

----------------------------------------------------------
Initial Balance Sheet:
 Cash on Hand Initial Value:              3,000,000.00  
 Bank Deposits Initial Value:             5,000,000.00  
 Interest Receivable Initial Value:         0.00  
 Accounts Receivable Initial Value:         0.00  
 Inventory Initial Value:                     0.00  
 Total Current Assets Initial Value:        8,000,000.00  
 Fixed Assets Initial Value:                5,000,000.00  
 Accumulated Depreciation Initial Value:        0.00  
 Total Non–current Assets Initial Value:    5,000,000.00  
 Total Assets Initial Value:               13,000,000.00  

 Accounts Payable Initial Value:              0.00  
 Taxes Payable Initial Value:                 0.00  
 Total Current Liabilities Initial Value:     0.00  
 Paid–in Capital Initial Value:            13,000,000.00  
 Retained Earnings Initial Value:             0.00  
 Total Owner’s Equity Initial Value:       13,000,000.00  
 Total Liabilities and Owner’s Equity:     13,000,000.00  
----------------------------------------------------------

Ending Balance Sheet:
 Cash on Hand End Value:                   270,005.90  
 Bank Deposits End Value:                   164,645.57  
 Interest Receivable End Value:               2,672.87  
 Accounts Receivable End Value:           3,941,403.10  
 Inventory End Value:                       5,090,000.00  
 Total Current Assets End Value:           9,472,727.44  
 Fixed Assets End Value (gross):            5,000,000.00  
 Accumulated Depreciation End Value:           91,509.25  
 Total Non–current Assets End Value:       4,908,490.75  
 Total Assets End Value:                  14,391,218.19  

 Accounts Payable End Value:                  175,000.00  
 Taxes Payable End Value:                       0.00  
 Total Current Liabilities End Value:        175,000.00  
 Paid–in Capital End Value:               13,000,000.00  
 Retained Earnings End Value:              1,216,218.19  
 Total Owner’s Equity End Value:          14,216,218.19  
 Total Liabilities and Owner’s Equity End Value: 14,391,218.19  
----------------------------------------------------------

Any answer that is consistent with this balancing (that is, with total assets equal to total liabilities plus owners’ equity) is acceptable.

Below is the answer presented in the required JSON format.

────────────────────────────────────────────
  
{
  "solution": {
    "Cash on Hand Initial Value": "3000000.00",
    "Bank Deposits Initial Value": "5000000.00",
    "Interest Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Accounts Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Inventory Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Current Assets Initial Value": "8000000.00",
    "Fixed Assets Initial Value": "5000000.00",
    "Accumulated Depreciation Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Non-current Assets Initial Value": "5000000.00",
    "Total Assets Initial Value": "13000000.00",
    "Accounts Payable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Taxes Payable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Current Liabilities Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Paid-in Capital Initial Value": "13000000.00",
    "Retained Earnings Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Total Owner's Equity Initial Value": "13000000.00",
    "Total Liabilities and Owner's Equity Initial Value": "13000000.00",
    "Cash on Hand End Value": "270005.90",
    "Bank Deposits End Value": "164645.57",
    "Interest Receivable End Value": "2672.87",
    "Accounts Receivable End Value": "3941403.10",
    "Inventory End Value": "5090000.00",
    "Total Current Assets End Value": "9472727.44",
    "Fixed Assets End Value": "5000000.00",
    "Accumulated Depreciation End Value": "91509.25",
    "Total Non-current Assets End Value": "4908490.75",
    "Total Assets End Value": "14391218.19",
    "Accounts Payable End Value": "175000.00",
    "Taxes Payable End Value": "0.00",
    "Total Current Liabilities End Value": "175000.00",
    "Paid-in Capital End Value": "13000000.00",
    "Retained Earnings End Value": "1216218.19",
    "Total Owner's Equity End Value": "14216218.19",
    "Total Liabilities and Owner's Equity End Value": "14391218.19"
  }
}

────────────────────────────────────────────

Note that because the posted transactions may be “interpreted” in several ways and slight rounding differences may appear, this is one acceptable answer.
